div1.p: Carter writes about her success in locating a particularly elusive reference.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, November 16, 1928

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
November 16, 1928.

div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have put in another very satisfactory
week's work--not our customary seven-day-week, however, as, for the
first time since our association, we spent the week-end out of town, in
Virginia. I feel that this brief experience of “out of doors” shoiuld be
of benefit to the book as well as to ourselves.

We had a piece of very good luck this week in the arrival of
another copy of Villalba's epidemiology at the Library of the Surgeon Gener
al. Mr. Neumann had ordered a duplicate copy as soon as it seemed use-
less to search longer for the missing one, but none of us had any idea
that his correspondent in Spain could get hold of a copy so quickly, as
they are said to be very rare. The edition just received is not the
same as the one that Father consulted, but I doubt if there be much difference.
Mr. Neumann also very kindly called us up at the Library of Congress as
soon as the book was received, reserving it for us in the interim. We
are “digging in” on Villalba then in order to let Dr. Frost have the veri-
fied references as soon as possible. I am delighted at the arrival of
this book before Father's MS goes to press, as we have been able to find
no reference to any copy in America save the missing one at tjhe Surgeon
General's Library.

Most of our remaining work is being done at the Library of Con-
gress amd at my apartment, but we still habve a table at the Library of tjhe
Surgeon General and, as in the present instance, the co-operation and help
there given us could be secured nowhere else. Also, I am glad for the sake of
its staff that we could get through the very large mass of literatire we
went over there when they were less busy than they are now after tjethe op-
-2-
workers.

It was delightful to get a glimpse of you Simunday night, only
I wish it had not had to be such a brief one. I hoped against hope
that you might have a spare moment before you left Washington and
shall continue to hope for better luck next time. It seemed very natiural
to see you here, reminding me of the wonderful talks between yourself
and Father to which I was priveleged to listen, and of all that our as-
sociation with yourself and the Foundation meant to both of us.
div1.closer:
With very best wishes, I remain
Most truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter, Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundatiom,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
P. S. Your letter of November 12th. jhas just reached me. It was very
thoughtful of you to remember my troubles about Villalba, but the arrival
of the copy from Spain will, I feel sure, put an end to our difficulties im
that line. We're going to have a splendid bibliography when we get through
and, thank Heaven! the bulk of it is done, though there are still some
things I am very anxious to clear up. Villalba was one of our main dif-
ficulties, however, so I trust he is an omen as to the rest!
